unnormalised: The Indian tax system is a complex framework governed by numerous laws and regulations. Recent amendments to tax laws, particularly in areas like the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and Income Tax Act, have significantly impacted businesses and individuals alike. unnormalised: One key amendment pertains to Sec. 44AD of the Income Tax Act, which deals with presumptive taxation for small businesses. The revised threshold for eligibility has been increased to ₹3 crore, provided that cash transactions do not exceed 5% of the total turnover. This change is intended to encourage digital transactions and provide relief to smaller enterprises. Similarly, under GST, there have been modifications to the e-invoicing rules, now applicable to businesses with an aggregate turnover exceeding Rs. 5 crores annually.
normalised: One key amendment pertains to Section four hundred and forty A-D of the Income Tax Act, which deals with presumptive taxation for small businesses. The revised threshold for eligibility has been increased to rupee three crore, provided that cash transactions do not exceed five percent of the total turnover. This change is intended to encourage digital transactions and provide relief to smaller enterprises. Similarly, under G-S-T, there have been modifications to the e-invoicing rules, now applicable to businesses with an aggregate turnover exceeding rupees five crores annually.

unnormalised: Another significant development is the introduction of new provisions related to digital assets. As per the Finance Act, income from the transfer of virtual digital assets (VDAs) is now taxable at a rate of 30%, with no deduction allowed for any expenditure or allowance. This has brought clarity and regulation to the previously ambiguous area of cryptocurrency taxation. Furthermore, TDS at 1% is applicable on transactions exceeding Rs. 10000 for specified persons.

unnormalised: The government has also focused on streamlining tax compliance and reducing litigation. The Vivad se Vishwas scheme, introduced in 2020, provides a mechanism for settling pending tax disputes by paying a reduced amount. This initiative has proven successful in reducing the backlog of cases and generating revenue. Furthermore, the implementation of faceless assessment procedures has aimed to enhance transparency and efficiency in the tax administration.
